questions.question:
Question 2: You are volunteering in a medical camp held in an orphanage. You see a kid with hypoplasia 
of the zygoma and mandible along with antimongoloid slant of palpebral fissures as shown 
below. These findings correspond to which of the following syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The given findings correspond to Treacher–Collins syndrome. Treacher–Collins syndrome/Mandibulofacial dysostosis refers to a condition resulting from the 
hypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible. Ocular features: • Indistinct inferior orbital margin • Coloboma of the lower eyelid • Anti-mongoloid slant of palpebral fissures Systemic features • Macrostomia with a high-arched palate • External ear deformity • Bird-like face The image below shows features of Treacher–Collins syndrome. Craniofacial dysostosis/Crouzon syndrome refers to the premature closure of the coronal and 
sagittal sutures (brachycephaly—clover-leaf skull) associated with maxillary hypoplasia. Ocular 
associations include the following: • Blue sclera • Megalocornea • Aniridia • Glaucoma • Cataract • Ectopia lentis • Optic nerve hypoplasia 412 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows a baby with Crouzon syndrome. Apert syndrome is the most severe form of craniosynostosis, involving premature closure of 
multiple cranial sutures (acrocephaly), along with syndactyly of the fingers and toes. The image below shows the hands of a patient with Apert syndrome.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario plus the supportive CT image showing the "hanging drop sign" is 
suggestive of a blowout fracture of the orbital wall. Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbit 
that results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure. 
This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial 413 
Sold by @itachibot portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor. The second most common site for orbital 
blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit. The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and blood 
extravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema or 
hemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common. Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments and 
orbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called as 
the "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign". Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportive 
management with analgesics and antibiotics. Le fort fracture- Is the term used to describe different types of maxillary fractures.

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most common site of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit. Blow-out fractures are isolated comminunited fractures caused from direct trauma to the orbit 
that results in a backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in the intraorbital pressure. 
This causes a fracture at the weakest point of the orbital wall which is usually the posteromedial 
portion of the maxillary bone in the orbital floor. The second most common site for orbital blowout fracture is the medial wall of the orbit (Option 
A). The fractures of the roof(Option C) are relatively rare and most often do not require any 
treatment.The lateral wall(Option B) of the orbit is the most solid orbital wall and a fracture here 
is usually seen in injuries with extensive facial damage. The patient with blow out fracture usually presents with immediate periorbital edema and blood 
extravasation in and around the orbit. Proptosis of the eyeball secondary to orbital edema or 
hemorrhage with paresthesia along the infraorbital nerve are also very common. Imaging by a plain x-ray in water's view or by CT demonstrates depression of bony fragments and 
orbital contents herniating through the orbital floor into the maxillary antrum. This is called as 
the "hanging drop sign" or "tear drop sign". Definitive treatment is by surgical repair 10-14 days after injury with initial supportive 
management with analgesics and antibiotics. The below given CT image shows hanging drop sign. 414

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following statements regarding the clinical sequelae expected in a patient with 
orbital blowout fracture is false?

options.a: Anesthesia of the cheek is very common.
options.b: Emphysema of eyelids is more common with medial wall fracture.
options.c: Enophthalmos develops about 10 days after the injury.
options.d: Severe ocular damage is seen in most cases.

questions.explanation:
Severe ocular damage associated with a "blowout" fracture is rare. This is because a "blowout fracture" is nature’s way of protecting the globe from injury. Clinical features of blow out fracture are as follows: • Periorbital edema • Paresthesia and anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of 
the nose, upper lip, and upper teeth) • Emphysema of the eyelids-more frequent with medial wall fractures 415 
Sold by @itachibot • Proptosis-seen initially due to orbital edema and hemorrhage. • After about 10 days, as the edema decreases, the eyeball sinks backward and somewhat 
inferiorly, resulting in enophthalmos and mechanical ptosis. • Double diplopia- diplopia in upward as well as downward gaze

questions.question:
Question 6: Two people who got in a brawl are brought to the emergency department because of severe 
facial injuries. In one of those patients, there is periorbital ecchymosis and anesthesia over 
the cheek. Orbital blowout fracture is suspected. What X-ray finding will confirm this 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The X-ray finding seen in an orbital blowout fracture is hanging drop/tear-drop sign. Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents 
the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The most 
useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view. The optimal time for surgery following a blowout fracture is 10–14 days. Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture are as follows: • Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma • A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum • Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanation 
tension on attempted upward gaze • Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm

questions.question:
Question 7: All of the following are characteristic clinical findings that are associated with a history of 
blunt trauma to the eye, except:
questions.explanation:
Vossius ring, not Soemmering’s, is seen after blunt trauma to the eye Soemmering’s ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract, also known as "secondary cataract." It is 
the opacity that persists or develops after extracapsular lens extraction. 416 
Sold by @itachibot Blunt trauma to the eye produces: • Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to 
the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens. • Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract. • Commotio retinae (Berlin’s edema) - It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a 
considerable area of the posterior pole with a "cherry-red spot" at foveola.

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common site of globe rupture following trauma?
questions.explanation:
The superonasal limbus is the most common site of globe rupture. This occurs due to the contrecoup effect—the lower temporal quadrant is the most exposed to 
trauma; hence, the effect is seen in the superonasal limbus, which lies on the opposite side.

The image shows bilateral periorbital ecchymoses, which is called the panda sign, and it is seen in 
bilateral anterior cranial fossa fracture. It is also known as panda eyes/raccoon eyes. The pooling of blood surrounding the eyes is most commonly associated with fractures of the 
anterior cranial fossa. This finding is typically not present during the initial evaluation and is 
delayed by 1 to 3 days. If bilateral, this finding is highly predictive of a basilar skull fracture.

questions.question:
Question 10: Clinical examination patients with which of the following conditions would show Dalen Fuchs 
Nodules?
questions.explanation:
Dalen Fuchs nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis and Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease 
(VKH) syndrome. These are local granulomas due to the proliferation of lymphocytes and epithelioid cells and are 
located between RPE and Bruch's membrane. The image below shows Dalen Fuchs nodules. 417

questions.explanation:
The Rhese view in an X-ray scan helps in the visualization of the optic foramina. The optic foramen/optic canal transmits the optic nerve and ophthalmic artery. questions.question: Question 12: Heterochromia iridis may be caused by which of the following intraocular foreign bodies?
questions.explanation:
Heterochromia iridis may be caused by iron deposition. Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. In 
siderosis bulbi, the iris is first stained greenish and later turns reddish brown, causing 
heterochromia iridis. Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye. Clinical 
features include the following: • Kayser–Fleischer ring- a golden brown ring that occurs due to the deposition of copper in the 
Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. • Sunflower cataract- produced by the deposition of copper under the anterior capsule of the lens. 
It is brilliant golden green in color and arranged like the petals of a sunflower. The image below shows siderosis bulbi. 419

a cleaning agent that contains ammonia. Ocular examination finding is given below.

Chemical injuries to the eye: • Alkali burns are twice as common as acid burns. • Alkalis tend to penetrate more deeply than acids, as the latter coagulate surface proteins,
